unnormalised: ## The Great Bijli Bill Blunder of '24
normalised: ## The Great Bijli Bill Blunder of twenty twenty four

unnormalised: So, let me tell you about the latest drama in my life – a saga involving the electricity bill, a frantic search for my reading glasses, and a near-existential crisis. It all started on the 5th of June, when I received that ominous envelope. My 'bijli' bill, as we lovingly call it in Mumbai.
normalised: So, let me tell you about the latest drama in my life – a saga involving the electricity bill, a frantic search for my reading glasses, and a near-existential crisis. It all started on the fifth of June, when I received that ominous envelope. My 'bijli' bill, as we lovingly call it in Mumbai.

unnormalised: Now, I'm usually pretty good about keeping track of our expenses. We're a middle-class family, you see, and every rupee counts. My husband, Rohan, is particularly meticulous. He’s got spreadsheets for everything, from our monthly grocery budget (Rs. 8000, give or take) to our investments in the stock market. He always says, “Aisha, knowledge is power, especially when it comes to finance!” But I digress.
normalised: Now, I'm usually pretty good about keeping track of our expenses. We're a middle-class family, you see, and every rupee counts. My husband, Rohan, is particularly meticulous. He’s got spreadsheets for everything, from our monthly grocery budget (rupees eight thousand, give or take) to our investments in the stock market. He always says, “Aisha, knowledge is power, especially when it comes to finance!” But I digressed.

unnormalised: Back to the bill. I tore open the envelope, expecting the usual amount – somewhere around Rs. 2500 to Rs. 3000, given the Mumbai heat and our reliance on the AC. But what I saw almost made me faint. Rs. 15,785! Fifteen thousand, seven hundred and eighty-five rupees! I had to read it again. And again. And again. My first thought was, "Did we accidentally power the entire neighbourhood?"
normalised: Back to the bill. I tore open the envelope, expecting the usual amount – somewhere around rupees two thousand five hundred to rupees three thousand, given the Mumbai heat and our reliance on the A-C. But what I saw almost made me faint. Rupees fifteen thousand, seven hundred and eighty five! Fifteen thousand, seven hundred and eighty-five rupees! I had to read it again. And again. And again. My first thought was, "Did we accidentally power the entire neighbourhood?"

unnormalised: I called Rohan immediately, practically screaming into the phone. "Fifteen thousand rupees! What happened? Did you leave the geyser on for a month straight?" Rohan, ever the calm one, told me to take a deep breath and check the meter readings. He was on his way home from work near CST, but he was already pulling up our past bills to compare the units consumed. Bless his organizational skills.

Rohan, ever the calm one, told me to take a deep breath and check the meter readings. He was on his way home from work near C-S-T, but he was already pulling up our past bills to compare the units consumed. Bless his organizational skills.

unnormalised: Armed with a magnifying glass (my eyesight isn't what it used to be, blame the late-night Bollywood movies), I ventured out to the electricity meter. The current reading was... well, let's just say it didn't match the bill. Not even close. It was a whopping 500 units less than what they had charged us for. At that point, I was convinced there had to be some sort of clerical error.

The current reading was... well, let's just say it didn't match the bill. Not even close. It was a whopping five hundred units less than what they had charged us for. At that point, I was convinced there had to be some sort of clerical error.

unnormalised: The next morning, bright and early (okay, relatively early – 9:00 AM sharp), I marched down to the BEST (Bombay Electric Supply and Transport) office. It was a chaotic scene, as always. People were yelling, paperwork was flying, and the air was thick with the scent of chai and frustration. I took a number (47, of course, and they were only on number 12) and settled in for the long haul.
normalised: The next morning, bright and early (okay, relatively early – nine A-M sharp), I marched down to the B-E-S-T (Bombay Electric Supply and Transport) office. It was a chaotic scene, as always. People were yelling, paperwork was flying, and the air was thick with the scent of chai and frustration. I took a number (forty seven, of course, and they were only on number twelve) and settled in for the long haul.

unnormalised: After what felt like an eternity, I finally got to speak to a very patient (and slightly weary) clerk. I explained my situation, showed her the bill, and pointed out the discrepancy in the meter readings. She listened intently, typed furiously on her keyboard, and then, with a sigh, said, "Madam, it seems there was an error. We apologize for the inconvenience. We will issue a revised bill for Rs. 2850."

We will issue a revised bill for rupees two thousand eight hundred and fifty."

unnormalised: Relief washed over me like a cool monsoon shower. Rs. 2850 – that sounded much more like it! It's a reminder, though, always double-check those bills. You never know when a simple mistake can turn into a financial rollercoaster. And perhaps, it’s time I invested in better reading glasses.
